results.abstract: Profile of and interview with Marcia Gay Harden, nominated for Academy Award for her supporting role in Pollock; photo (L) (Special supplement on the Oscars)0

headline.main: Her Friends Know What a Big Deal This Is

results.snippet: MOSTLY, Marcia Gay Harden's boxy oceanfront apartment resembled a dressing room on opening night. The telephone never stopped trilling and, four days after she was nominated as best supporting actress for her performance as the artist Lee Krasner in...
results.lead_paragraph: MOSTLY, Marcia Gay Harden's boxy oceanfront apartment resembled a dressing room on opening night. The telephone never stopped trilling and, four days after she was nominated as best supporting actress for her performance as the artist Lee Krasner in the film ''Pollock,'' every available surface was crowded with enormous floral arrangements from producers, agents and industry honchos. The bowl of beautiful pink roses and lavender sweet peas was from Winona Ryder, whom Ms. Harden doesn't even know. Taped to the front door and over the mantel were full-color trade-paper ads congratulating her. Perhaps Ms. Harden was feeling self-conscious about the wall art. She got up from her brown leather couch and began pulling down the makeshift banners. ''Thad? Honey?'' Ms. Harden called out to Thaddaeus Scheel, her husband of six years.

results.abstract: Interview with artist Paul Calle of Stanford, Conn, who designed US postage stamp commemorating first moon landing and whose works are included in exhibition of artists' concepts of space at Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn; photos (M)

headline.main: Imagining Trips Into Space With Artist at the Controls

results.snippet: THE current major exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich is a seamless mix of science and art. ''Space 2001: to the Moon and Beyond'' contains what artists and writers once imagined space travel to be like, along with paintings based on evidence...
results.lead_paragraph: THE current major exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich is a seamless mix of science and art. ''Space 2001: to the Moon and Beyond'' contains what artists and writers once imagined space travel to be like, along with paintings based on evidence gained from the actual moon voyages. There are also real items like a space suit worn by Neil Armstrong. Some of the featured artists, including Paul Calle, who lives in Stamford and has a studio in Ridgefield, participated in NASA's art program, which was started in 1963. In 1969, Mr. Calle designed the United States postage stamp that commemorated the first landing on the moon. Recently Mr. Calle talked about his involvement with that program, his art and other matters.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery to blast off on mission to International Space Station (S)

headline.main: Shuttle Primed for Crew-Exchange Mission to Station

results.snippet: The space shuttle Discovery's mission to the International Space Station is a mission of firsts -- but it should be repeated so often in the future that eventually hardly anyone will notice.    The Discovery, with two groups of astronauts, is...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Discovery's mission to the International Space Station is a mission of firsts -- but it should be repeated so often in the future that eventually hardly anyone will notice. The Discovery, with two groups of astronauts, is scheduled to blast off on Thursday for the first crew exchange on the new station. The shuttle is also taking up the first of a new type of moving van designed to make routine trips hauling cargo and experiments to and from the station.

results.snippet: The International Space Station's first replacement crew entered its new home this morning after the space shuttle Discovery docked with the space station.    Yuri V. Usachev, a Russian astronaut, and two Americans -- Col. James S. Voss, retired, and...
results.lead_paragraph: The International Space Station's first replacement crew entered its new home this morning after the space shuttle Discovery docked with the space station. Yuri V. Usachev, a Russian astronaut, and two Americans -- Col. James S. Voss, retired, and Col. Susan B. Helms of the Air Force -- will take over for a three-member crew that has been aboard the station for four months. They will move in over the next several days.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery astronauts Col James S Voss and Col Susan J Helms install hardware and move equipment on International Space Station in spacewalk of almost nine hours that is longest in history of shuttle program (S)

headline.main: 2 Astronauts Walk in Space Almost 9 Hours

results.snippet: Two astronauts installed hardware and moved equipment early today on the International Space Station, in the process completing the longest spacewalk in the history of the shuttle program.    The astronauts, Col. James S. Voss of the Army, retired,...
results.lead_paragraph: Two astronauts installed hardware and moved equipment early today on the International Space Station, in the process completing the longest spacewalk in the history of the shuttle program. The astronauts, Col. James S. Voss of the Army, retired, and Col. Susan J. Helms of the Air Force, had finished their work on space station Alpha but could not end their spacewalk until flight controllers determined their help was not needed in relocating a docking port to make way for an Italian module filled with supplies.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Discovery astronauts Dr Andrew S W Thomas and Paul W Richards take space walk to finish critical wiring job on international space station (S)

headline.main: 2 Astronauts Leave Shuttle to Finish Job

results.snippet: Two astronauts floated outside the shuttle Discovery early today to finish a critical wiring job on the International Space  Station.    The two, Dr. Andrew S. W. Thomas and Paul W. Richards took on the work that was left undone during Sunday's...
results.lead_paragraph: Two astronauts floated outside the shuttle Discovery early today to finish a critical wiring job on the International Space Station. The two, Dr. Andrew S. W. Thomas and Paul W. Richards took on the work that was left undone during Sunday's record-breaking nine-hour spacewalk by two other astronauts.

results.abstract: International Space Station and shuttle Discovery dodge piece of space junk, large tool that astronaut dropped earlier in week; mission commander, Capt James D Wetherbee, fires shuttle's thrusters to move joined spacecraft to higher orbit (S)

headline.main: National News Briefs; Shuttle and Station Dodge Tool in Space

results.snippet: The International Space Station and the shuttle Discovery dodged a piece of space junk today, a  large tool that an astronaut dropped earlier in the week.    The mission commander, Capt. James D. Wetherbee of the Navy, fired the shuttle's thrusters...
results.lead_paragraph: The International Space Station and the shuttle Discovery dodged a piece of space junk today, a large tool that an astronaut dropped earlier in the week. The mission commander, Capt. James D. Wetherbee of the Navy, fired the shuttle's thrusters to move the joined spacecraft to a higher orbit. Without the maneuver, the 12-by-6-inch viselike tool, which Col. James S. Voss of the Army dropped in a spacewalk on Sunday, would have passed within 200 feet of the complex. Such an object could punch a hole in a spacecraft, killing everyone on board.

results.abstract: Editorial lauds Mir space station, which was launched in 1986 and will soon fall out of earth orbit; says it embodies significant chunk of orbital history (M)
results.snippet: When the Mir space station was launched on Feb. 20, 1986, its name, which means ''peace,'' was an overture of sorts in a still-suspicious time. As it turned out, the spaceship went on to embody peace in practice, becoming a place where more than 100...
results.lead_paragraph: When the Mir space station was launched on Feb. 20, 1986, its name, which means ''peace,'' was an overture of sorts in a still-suspicious time. As it turned out, the spaceship went on to embody peace in practice, becoming a place where more than 100 humans have lived high above Earth, slightly more than half from the former Soviet Union and the rest from more than a dozen other countries including the United States. Mir lasted far longer than expected, becoming the longest-running manned platform ever mounted in space and a significant contributor to scientific knowledge. Now the 135-ton Mir is coming down, its re-entry to Earth's atmosphere and inevitable destruction scheduled for later this week. Its demise -- dictated by creaky components and lack of money to upgrade them -- will remove the last remaining symbol of Russia's glory days in space.

results.abstract: Two Russian scheduled to fly to International Space Station, boycotts training session to protest NASA's exclusion of California millionaire Dennis Tito--who hopes to become world's first space tourist--from their crew (S)

headline.main: Tourist Barred, Russia Boycotts NASA Training

results.snippet: Two Russian astronauts who are supposed to fly to the International Space Station next month boycotted a training session today to protest NASA's exclusion of a California millionaire from their crew.    The incident was the most embarrassing and...
results.lead_paragraph: Two Russian astronauts who are supposed to fly to the International Space Station next month boycotted a training session today to protest NASA's exclusion of a California millionaire from their crew. The incident was the most embarrassing and public confrontation yet in a monthslong power struggle between NASA and the Russian Space Agency over tourism in space.

results.abstract: Interactive robotic toys, big feature at recent Toy Fair, are crammed with sophisticated electronics and software to sense obstacles, recognize simple speech, respond to commands, detect light and move; may help usher in era in not too distant future of practical, utilitarian robots that can serve humans; photos (M)
results.snippet: AT the annual Toy Fair last month, the huge annual show in New York where the toy industry promotes its newest creations, robots were everywhere.    Tiger Electronics, a division of Hasbro, showed off no less than two dozen interactive robotic toys...
results.lead_paragraph: AT the annual Toy Fair last month, the huge annual show in New York where the toy industry promotes its newest creations, robots were everywhere. Tiger Electronics, a division of Hasbro, showed off no less than two dozen interactive robotic toys that it plans to unleash next holiday season. They include a free-ranging turtle and other automatons for the fish bowl, as well as a gleaming, robotic baby that coos while responding to touch, sight and sound. There were plenty of robotic toys from other manufacturers, too: more dogs than you can throw a stick at, joined by cats, birds, mice, bugs, dinosaurs and even potted plants.

results.abstract: Mir space station streaks back to Earth in controlled descent, ending 15 years as orbiting laboratory for Soviet and then Russian science; Russian space agency at Mission Control near Moscow handles descent with remarkable precision; witnesses on Fiji report spectacular display of gold and silver lights streaming across sky as Mir crashes into ocean about 1,800 miles east of New Zealand; efforts to save Mir by turning it into movie set, tourist lodge or venue for television series came too late; photo (M)

headline.main: Mir Space Station Sizzles to Ending Over Pacific

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS

results.snippet: The Mir space station streaked back to Earth today as a molten blaze of metal and fire, harmlessly raking a swath of the South Pacific like a load of cosmic buckshot.    The controlled descent, which ended Mir's 15-year-career as an orbiting...
results.lead_paragraph: The Mir space station streaked back to Earth today as a molten blaze of metal and fire, harmlessly raking a swath of the South Pacific like a load of cosmic buckshot. The controlled descent, which ended Mir's 15-year-career as an orbiting laboratory for Soviet and then Russian science, was managed with remarkable precision by the Russian space agency at Mission Control here near Moscow. Fifteen minutes before the scheduled splashdown, Russian officials announced that an American ground station on Guam had confirmed that Mir was descending through the atmosphere according to plan, following a final burn of its retro-rocket system.

results.snippet: ''I am especially sad these days. An entire era of our Soviet space program is ending, into which we invested not only our money but, what is more important, our intellectual potential.''    ANATOLY SOLOVYOV, a Russian astronaut who spent 651 days on...
results.lead_paragraph: ''I am especially sad these days. An entire era of our Soviet space program is ending, into which we invested not only our money but, what is more important, our intellectual potential.'' ANATOLY SOLOVYOV, a Russian astronaut who spent 651 days on Mir. [A1]
